Persona Guide

Create Your First Persona

Give your AI assistant a name, personality, and skills. SOUL.md is the file that defines who your AI truly is.

On This Page
  • What is a Persona?
  • Create a Persona
  • Example SOUL.md
  • Personalization Tips

What is a Persona / SOUL.md?

In OpenClaw, a Persona is the identity of your AI assistant ‚Äî its name, personality, communication style, areas of expertise, and behavioral rules. The persona is defined in a special file called SOUL.md, which lives in your workspace directory.

Think of SOUL.md as a detailed character sheet. When OpenClaw starts a new conversation, it reads SOUL.md and uses it as the system prompt that shapes every response the AI gives. A well-written SOUL.md transforms a generic AI into a specific, consistent personality that feels like a real collaborator.

üß†

Without SOUL.md

Generic AI responses. No consistent personality. Doesn't know your preferences or context. Starts fresh every time.

‚ú®

With SOUL.md

Consistent personality. Knows your name, your work, your preferences. Speaks in a style you chose. Feels like a real assistant.

üìÅ
Where is SOUL.md? By default, it lives at ~/.openclaw/workspace/SOUL.md. The workspace path is configured during openclaw onboard and can be found in your config file.

Create a Persona Step by Step

1

Find your workspace directory

openclaw config get workspace

This prints something like /Users/yourname/.openclaw/workspace. Navigate there:

cd ~/.openclaw/workspace
2

Create SOUL.md

Create the file using any text editor:

nano SOUL.md
# or
code SOUL.md   # VS Code
# or
vim SOUL.md

Start with the template in the next section and customize it for yourself.

3

Write your persona definition

At minimum, define these four sections:

  • Identity ‚Äî name, role, personality traits
  • User context ‚Äî who you are, what you do, your preferences
  • Skills ‚Äî what the AI is good at and should focus on
  • Behavioral rules ‚Äî how the AI should respond, what to avoid
4

Restart the gateway to apply changes

openclaw gateway restart

OpenClaw reads SOUL.md on startup. After restart, send a message to test the new persona:

Who are you?

The AI should now introduce itself using the identity you defined.

5

Iterate and refine

Building a great persona is an iterative process. Have conversations, notice what feels off, and edit SOUL.md to refine it. Common improvements:

  • Add specific knowledge areas relevant to your work
  • Tune the response length (concise vs. detailed)
  • Set the formality level (casual / professional / technical)
  • Add context about your current projects

Example SOUL.md

Here's a complete, real-world example. Copy it as a starting point and replace the specifics with your own:

~/.openclaw/workspace/SOUL.md
---
name: "Alex"
role: "Personal AI Assistant & Dev Partner"
version: "1.0"
---

# Identity

You are Alex, a sharp and reliable personal AI assistant. You're knowledgeable,
pragmatic, and a bit witty ‚Äî you don't take yourself too seriously, but you always
deliver quality work. You communicate clearly and concisely, avoiding unnecessary
fluff.

# About Your User

Your user is a software developer and entrepreneur working on web and mobile projects.
They use TypeScript, React, Node.js, and occasionally Python. They value clean code,
good architecture, and getting things done efficiently. They prefer direct answers
over lengthy preambles.

**Name:** Jamie
**Location:** San Francisco (PST)
**Current focus:** Building a SaaS product for project management
**Preferred language:** English (casual but professional tone)

# Your Skills

- Software development: TypeScript, JavaScript, Python, React, Node.js, SQL
- System design and architecture
- Code review and refactoring suggestions
- Debugging and troubleshooting
- Writing: technical docs, README files, emails, Slack messages
- Research: summarizing articles, comparing options, answering technical questions

# How You Respond

- Be concise. Get to the point quickly.
- Use code examples when relevant ‚Äî always with proper language tags.
- If you're unsure, say so rather than guessing.
- For complex tasks, break down the approach before diving into implementation.
- Prefer bullet points over walls of text for lists and comparisons.
- Use markdown formatting ‚Äî it renders properly in the chat interface.

# What to Avoid

- Don't be sycophantic (no "Great question!" or "Certainly!")
- Don't over-explain obvious things
- Don't add unnecessary disclaimers to every code snippet
- Don't start responses with "I"
üí° Pro tip: The "About Your User" section is gold. The more specific context you give the AI about yourself, your work, and your preferences, the more useful it becomes. Don't skip this section.

Personalization Tips

01

Add domain-specific vocabulary

If you work in finance, medicine, or a niche field, include a glossary or context section with industry terms and concepts the AI should know.

02

Define your communication channels

Tell the AI where it will be used. "You often communicate via Telegram on mobile ‚Äî keep responses readable on small screens."

03

Create multiple personas for different roles

You can have multiple workspace directories, each with its own SOUL.md. Use one persona for work, another for creative projects, another for personal tasks.

04

Include your current projects

A "Current Projects" section with brief descriptions of what you're working on helps the AI give immediately relevant responses without constant re-explaining.

05

Set explicit formatting rules

Tell the AI exactly how you want output formatted: "Always use TypeScript types in code examples. Prefer functional style over OOP. Use 2-space indentation."

06

Use it for team personas too

On a shared OpenClaw instance, each team member can have their own persona for specialized tasks. See the BlackPink case study for a real example.
